content:
{{knowledge objective
|Identifiant=OIC-265-11-A
|Item_parent=Urinary lithiasis
|Item_parent_short=Urinary lithiasis
|Rank=A
|Title=Knowing the emergency biological tests to be carried out for renal colic
|Description=(Urine dipstick), CBC, ionogram, creatininaemia, CRP
|Rubric=Additional tests
|Contributors=Romain Boissier
|Order=11}}


== Biological tests carried out in the emergency department are designed to identify severe/complicated forms of renal colic: ==

*urine dipstick
*cytobacteriological examination of urine,
*blood cultures if febrile renal colic is suspected,
*serum creatinine measurement.

question.title: What additional biological test is NOT typically carried out in the emergency department for renal colic?
question.description: A test to identify severe/complicated forms of renal colic

option_a.title: Urine dipstick
option_a.description: A common test for diagnosing renal colic

option_b.title: Cytobacteriological examination of urine
option_b.description: A test to identify bacterial infections in the urine

option_c.title: Blood cultures if febrile renal colic is suspected
option_c.description: A test to identify bacterial infections in the blood

option_d.title: Serum creatinine measurement
option_d.description: A test to measure kidney function

correct_option.title: Blood cultures
correct_option.description: The correct answer, as blood cultures are not typically used to diagnose renal colic
